article:
{{multiple issues|

|disputed = August 2012|contradict = August 2012}}


'Lightning' is a massive electrostatic discharge caused by unbalanced electrical
charges between different regions of the atmosphere which temporarily equalize
themselves through a lightning 'flash', commonly referred to as a strike. There
are three primary types; from a cloud to itself (IC); from one cloud to another
cloud (CC) and finally between a cloud and the ground (CG). Often it is
accompanied by the sound of thunder.

Lightning occurs approximately 40â50 times a second worldwide, resulting in
nearly 1.4 billion flashes per year.

Many factors affect the frequency, distribution, strength, and physical
properties of a "typical" lightning flash to a particular region of the world.
These factors include ground elevation, latitude, prevailing wind currents,
relative humidity, proximity to warm and cold bodies of water, etc. To a certain
degree, the ratio between IC, CC and CG lightning varies.

]]

Because man is terrestrial and most of his possessions are on the Earth, where
lightning can damage or destroy them, CG lightning is the most studied and best
understood of the three types, even though IC and CC are more common.
Lightning's unpredictability limits a complete explanation of how or why it
occurs, even after hundreds of years of scientific investigation. A typical
cloud to ground lightning flash forms an electrical channel through the air in
excess of 5 km (3 mi) allowing for 'discharge', the visible portion of
lightning, to occur through a complex process. Uman, Martin A.' "All About
Lightning"; p. 81; Dover Publications N.Y.; 1986; ISBN- 2-486-25237-x A
typical thunderstorm has three or more strikes to the Earth per minute at its
peak. Uman, Martin A.' "All About Lightning"; p. 55; Dover Publications
N.Y.; 1986; ISBN- 2-486-25237-x

, Utah, United States.]]

Lightning primarily occurs when warm air is mixed with colder air masses
resulting in atmospheric disturbances necessary for polarizing the atmosphere,
however it also occurs during dust storms, forest fires, tornadoes, volcanic
eruptions, and even in the cold of winter called thundersnow. [http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2010/02/100203-
volcanoes-lightning/ New Lightning Type Found Over Volcano?].
News.nationalgeographic.com (February 2010). Retrieved on June 23,
2012. Hurricanes typically generate some lightning, mainly in
the rainbands as much as 160 km (100 mi) from the
center. Hurricane lightning [http://nldr.library.ucar.edu/repository/assets/soars/SOARS-000-000-000-
193.pdf] Accesssed 27 Jul 2012 Hurricane Lightning [http://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-
nasa/2006/09jan_electrichurricanes/] Accessed 17 Jul 2012 Long Range
Lightning Detection Network [http://www.unidata.ucar.edu/committees/polcom/2009-
spring/statusreports/BusingerS09.pdf] Accessed 27 Jul 2012

The science of lightning is called [[fulminology]]. [http://www.wcl.govt.nz/blogs/kids/index.php/2008/07/17/a-
fulminologist-is-a/ A Fulminologist is aâ¦]. Wcl.govt.nz (2008-07-17). Retrieved
on June 23, 2012. The fear of lightning is called astraphobia.
headings: A lightning flash [strike]: a very complex process
